Title: A Computational Approach to Early Language Bootstrapping

This project aims to develop a computational model that simulates the early language acquisition process in infants, shedding light on the complex mechanisms underlying this critical period of human development. We will create a machine learning-based framework that integrates speech recognition, lexical analysis, and phonological rule extraction to model infant language learning. The model will be tested on speech databases in three languages (Japanese, French, and Dutch) and validated through behavioral and neurological studies with infants at 6, 9, and 12 months of age. Our approach will involve four subprojects: defining coding features for speech, word segmentation in raw speech, predictive modeling of coarticulation in auditory space, and iterative integration of approximate representations for phonemes, words, and contextual rules. We will evaluate the model's predictions using artificial languages and a longitudinal study, comparing its performance to state-of-the-art supervised phoneme recognizers. By elucidating the early language acquisition process, this project has the potential to inform language learning strategies, improve speech recognition technology, and enhance our understanding of language development and its disorders.

Here is a 302-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: A Computational Approach to Early Language Bootstrapping

This project aims to develop a computational model that simulates the early language acquisition process in infants, shedding light on the complex mechanisms underlying language development. Our approach combines machine learning, automatic speech recognition, and behavioral and neurological studies to investigate how infants acquire language skills between 6-12 months of age. We will focus on three languages: Japanese, French, and Dutch.

The project consists of four interconnected subprojects. First, we will define coding features for speech, exploring both fine-grained and coarse-grained representations. Second, we will develop a model for word segmentation in raw speech, recognizing that the infant lexicon is large and distinct from the adult lexicon. Third, we will create a predictive model of coarticulation in auditory space, using reverse coarticulation to simulate the infant's auditory experience. Finally, we will iteratively integrate approximate representations for phonemes, words, and contextual rules, assessing the model's performance on adult-directed and infant-directed speech databases.

To validate our model, we will employ two prediction testing methods: artificial languages and a longitudinal study. We will compare our model's performance to state-of-the-art supervised phoneme recognizers, providing a comprehensive understanding of early language bootstrapping. The proposed project has significant implications for language acquisition theory, speech recognition systems, and the development of language interventions for children with language disorders. By elucidating the mechanisms of early language acquisition, we can inform more effective language teaching methods and improve language outcomes for children worldwide.

Title: A Computational Approach to Early Language Bootstrapping

This project aims to develop a computational model that simulates the early language acquisition process in infants, shedding light on the mysteries of how young children rapidly acquire language skills. Our approach leverages machine learning, automatic speech recognition, and behavioral and neurological studies to create a comprehensive framework for understanding language development.

We will focus on infants aged 6, 9, and 12 months, examining their acquisition of Japanese, French, and Dutch languages. The project is divided into four subprojects: (1) defining coding features for speech, exploring both fine-grained and coarse-grained approaches; (2) word segmentation in raw speech, recognizing that the infant lexicon is large and distinct from adult lexicons; (3) developing a predictive model of coarticulation in auditory space, using reverse coarticulation to inform our understanding; and (4) iteratively integrating approximate representations for phonemes, words, and contextual rules, assessing performance on adult-directed and infant-directed speech databases.

To validate our model, we will employ artificial languages and longitudinal studies to test its predictions. Comparative analysis will be conducted against state-of-the-art supervised phoneme recognizers. By integrating insights from machine learning, linguistics, and developmental psychology, this project has the potential to revolutionize our understanding of early language acquisition and inform the development of more effective language interventions and assessments. Ultimately, our work will contribute to the creation of more sophisticated artificial intelligence systems capable of human-like language understanding and generation.
